fields.body:
There are literally hundreds of actions you can do to reduce your energy use. At Repower at Home, we've selected actions that we believe are both impactful and simple. We've kept the action list small — under 30 — and focused our attention on making those actions as informative as possible.

Will you include X action?

While we want to focus on a few key actions, we’re always on the lookout for actions that make sense and save energy. If there’s an action you think we've overlooked, tell us about it by posting a comment or using the Feedback link up top.

How are points assigned to an action?

Points are generally indicative of how much energy you will save by completing an action. Unfortunately, this is not an exact science and we’re often in the position of comparing apples and oranges...or windows and light bulbs. As if that wasn't enough, every home is unique, and your results may vary significantly from a "typical" home.

Points also take into account other factors such as cost and ease of completing the action. Social actions, like posting to Twitter, don’t directly save energy, but do raise the profile of energy efficiency.

fields.body: Eco-minded actions like recycling or choosing reusable bags are definitely more visible changes than, say, insulating your attic. But while less obvious, steps that reduce your energy use at home are some of the most important things you can personally do to combat climate change. Direct energy use by American households accounts for around 38% of U.S. CO2 emissions.Dietz, Thomas et al., “Household actions can provide a behavioral wedge to rapidly reduce U.S. carbon emissions.” PNAS. 106.44 (2009) That means the emissions from American households are larger than the entire emissions of any other country except China. Ibid. Save money, save the world The good news is that our homes represent an enormous opportunity to significantly reduce global greenhouse gas emissions. Homeowners across the country have already realized these savings. The average household that had a retrofit in Maryland, for example, reduced their energy use by more than 20%. Maryland Energy Administration, Maryland Home Performance with ENERGY STARE Even smaller steps, like reducing your hot water use and upgrading your lighting, start to add up to big rewards. Best of all, you can personally have an impact on climate change while saving money. Not only is investing in building efficiency the most cost-effective way to combat climate change, it’s actually an overall cost savings.McKinsey & Company, Unlocking Energy Efficiency in the US Economy Investing in energy efficiency is like paying yourself to do the right thing. People across the country are getting geared up to make a big impact on energy waste and greenhouse gases. Take action in your own homes, and share the word with your friends, family, and neighbors. Together, all of our steps will make a world of difference.

fields.body:
Electric companies use kilowatt-hours (kWh) to measure your total energy use for the month...and then bill you accordingly. But, those rascals at the electric company don't actually explain what these strange things are. Is 1 kWh a lot or a little? Here's a rundown of what kilowatt-hours are all about.

Let's say you leave a 100 Watt lamp on for 1 hour. During that hour, the lamp uses 100 Watt-hours of energy (100 Watts x 1 hour). If you leave it on for 10 hours, it will use 1,000 Watt-hours — or 1 kilowatt-hour. So, every kilowatt-hour on your bill is equivalent to the energy used by a 100 Watt lamp on for 10 hours.

So, how many kilowatt-hours does your stuff use? Here are some estimates of monthly kilowatt-hour consumption:

  • A clock radio: 7.2 kWh. The clock radio is on 24 hours/day, and uses 10 Watts. " Estimating Appliance and Home Electronic Use." Energy Savers. 24 March 2009. 19 April 2010.
  • A newish refrigerator: 45 kWh. "Refrigerator Retirement Savings Calculator." ENERGY STAR. n.d. 15 April 2010
  • An LCD television: 27 kWh. A similarly-sized plasma television uses nearly twice that, at 53 kWh. The average household watched 5.2 hours of television in a day. The average plasma tested uses 338 Watts, while the average LCD uses 176 Watts. Katzmaier, David and Matthew Moskovciak. "The basics of TV power." CNET. 13 Nov 2009, 15 April 2010. And that's before you account for vampire power.

Now that you're an expert on kilowatt-hours, go forth and reduce your use. Your energy bill will thank you.

Extra credit: power vs. energy

People often use "power" and "energy" interchangeably, but they're different. Kilowatts are a unit of power, kilowatt-hours are a unit of energy. It's like the difference between speed and distance. Your speed is how fast you're going right now; your distance is how far you went during the trip. Similarly, kilowatts measure how much energy your lamp is using right now; kilowatt-hours measure how much energy it used while it was on. Class dismissed!

Repower at Home will help you turn your home into an energy efficient machine. With our actions to guide you, you'll save energy, save money, and do your part to save the world. And you can do it all from the comfort of your own home.

Get started by creating an account. Then complete you first mission by freeing your home from energy vampires. After you're done slaying some vampires, head over to the teams page. Once you join a team, you can swap tales of energy-saving glory and plan your next steps with other members. It's all in a day's work at Repower at Home.

There's a lot to do, but there's even more in the works. In the coming weeks, you can look forward to:

  • Richer content across many of our actions
  • New featured actions
  • Online tools for organizing your own Repower at Home events
  • Totally integrated design
  • And more!

Go ahead and start exploring now. If you run into problems, let us know by using the "Feedback" link up top. Welcome home!

American homes consume almost a quarter of all the energy used in the United States."Annual Energy Review." Figure 2.1a. Energy Information Agency. 26 June 2009 Much of this energy is needlessly wasted by outdated systems and habits. No longer! Repower at Home will show you how to turn your home into an energy efficient machine. By taking some simple steps, you'll save energy, save money, and do your part to save the world. All from the comfort of your own home.

American homes consume almost a quarter of all the energy used in the United States."Annual Energy Review." Figure 2.1a. Energy Information Agency. 26 June 2009 Unfortunately, much of this energy is needlessly wasted by outdated systems and habits. No longer! Repower at Home will show you how to put that energy to good use. And saving energy is just the beginning. By making your home more efficient, you'll also reap rewards like:

  • Lower monthly bills
  • Cleaner air
  • Better health
  • Greater comfort
  • Added value

More money? Yes, please! How do I get started? Get started by creating an account. As a registered user, you'll have full access to our library of actions. These actions provide a comprehensive plan for building a better home.

As you complete actions, you'll earn points and showcase your victories to other users. You'll also have access to teams, which allow you to connect with other energy-saving superstars near you. Together, you can share new ideas for how to get other members of your community off the bench and into the energy game.

And did we mention that Repower at Home is available for the rock bottom price of zero dollar? That's the best part of being a nonprofit — our only goal is to help you save energy. All of our information and services are, and always will be, completely free of charge.

Sign up today!

What's on deck? Repower at Home is a work in progress. As we grow, we’re excited to hear your feedback and suggestions for future content. As you click through the site, let us know how we’re doing by using the "Feedback" link up top.

fields.title: How To Repower Your Home

fields.body: Every month, we challenge all Repower@Home members to take one simple step to improve their energy use. This month, we're highlight the most effective tool you already own for reducing your heating and cooling bill: your thermostat. Everyone who programs their thermostat between now and February 28th will receive double the points for the action. Your thermostat may seem lowly, but it has the potential to make a huge difference. The secret: you have to use it. Around 70% of American households have thermostats,ENERGY STAR, Summary of Research Findings From the Programmable Thermostat Market but many of us are missing out on savings by not setting our thermostats correctly.Ibid. Saving money and energy with your thermostat is easy. Before you go to sleep or leave the house for the day, set back your thermostat. If you turn your thermostat from 72° to 62° during the winter, you could save 10% on your heating bill.U.S. Department of Energy, Energy Savers, Thermostats and Control Systems In the summer, raise your thermostat to 82°. It just takes a few moments every day, and you’ll quickly see real results. Programmable thermostats make saving energy automatic by raising or lowering your thermostat during certain times. There are many different models available, including ones that allow you to program different temperature settings for each day of the week. Your local home improvement store will likely offer a wide range of models. New models are also easier to set than some older versions. You can get started saving energy right away. Once programmed, you’ll never have to remember to set your thermostat again. You have everything to gain by programming your thermostat this month. Try it out, and let us know how it worked for you.

fields.body: If you think about it, you're energy bill is pretty weird. Every month, you receive the bill in the mail. But most of your bill just tells you how many kilowatt-hours you use — whatever those are — and how much you need pay. Where does that money go? The typical household spent $2,200 in energy bills in 2009.ENERGY STAR, Where Does My Money Go? However, some tasks needed considerably more energy than others. Identifying the biggest energy users in your home will help you make targeted improvements and get the best return on your investment. Average Home Energy Bill By Task In the chart, you can see that heating and cooling is by far the biggest energy user in most homes. It’s responsible for almost half of your energy bill, costing the average home around $1,000 a year to run. Small, inexpensive improvements – like installing new air sealing – can add up to huge rewards. Hot water is another, surprising energy-guzzler. Just heating your hot water uses more energy than running your refrigerator, microwave, and other appliances. By becoming more mindful of your hot water use while showering or washing clothes, you can eliminate waste and higher bills.
